docs.lead_paragraph: A professional society of New York cancer specialists asked state officials yesterday to investigate complaints by doctors who said they were encountering long delays in payments by one of metropolitan New York's largest insurers. The Manhattan-based division of the New York State Society of Medical Oncologists and Hemotologists said that its members were reporting payments overdue by 90 days to six months by Aetna U.S. Healthcare, a unit of Aetna Inc. The oncologists said Aetna was violating a New York law requiring payment of undisputed, or clean, bills to doctors and hospitals within 45 days.

headline.main: New York Doctors Group Faults Aetna on Payments

docs.abstract: New York State Society of Medical Oncologists and Hemotolgists unit asks state officials to probe complaints by members about long delays in payments by Aetna Inc's Aetna US Healthcare; holds Aetna violates state law requiring payment of undisputed bills within 45 days; Aetna says it has modified drug ordering process to speed up payments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats and Republicans revealed their election-year strategies on health care last week. Republicans want to cut taxes on uninsured individuals who buy coverage on their own. The Democrats seek to regulate managed-care plans that deny their members adequate care. Though each proposal is flawed, neither is extreme. There is room to find common ground. Bill Archer, chairman of the House tax-writing committee, is focusing on the key problem -- access to suitable health insurance. He is weighing proposals to provide a new tax deduction for individuals who buy coverage without help from their employers, and a larger deduction for families that run up large uncovered medical bills. But tax deductions will be expensive and difficult to target. They needlessly reward families that are already covered and skip over those that do not itemize deductions, a problem that could be solved by using tax credits rather than deductions. The proposal could also backfire, encouraging companies to disband existing coverage and inviting workers to buy policies on their own.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes that Democrats and Republicans have revealed their election-year strategies on health care; notes that Republicans want to cut taxes on uninsured individuals who buy coverage on their own, and Democrats seek to regulate managed-care plans that deny their members adequate care; contends that while each proposal is flawed, neither is extreme and there is room to find common ground (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ross Perot's computer services company has revoked health coverage for partners of newly hired gay employees. Gay rights advocates said today that his was the first corporation to reverse what they called a trend among businesses, especially in the computer industry, to grant these benefits. The Human Rights Campaign, a leading gay and lesbian political organization, protested the action by Mr. Perot's company, Perot Systems Inc., as a slap at homosexuals.

headline.main: Perot Ends Benefits for Partners of Newly Hired Gay Workers

docs.abstract: Perot Systems Inc, Ross Perot's computer services company, revokes health coverage for partners of newly hired gay employees; gay rights advocates say it is first corporation to reverse what they call trend among businesses to grant these benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton vowed today that he would continue to fight for tobacco legislation despite the intransigence of the cigarette manufacturers, and he promised the residents of this tobacco-growing community that their livelihoods would not be threatened by the bill. ''We don't have to wreck the fabric of life in your community,'' he declared in a speech in the Carroll County High School gymnasium. ''But even in tobacco country, we can't deny what the scientists have told us or what has been done to market tobacco to children.''

headline.main: Clinton, Visiting Tobacco Country, Tries to Win Over Farmers on Legislation

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, in speech at Carroll County (Ky) High School, vows that he will continue to fight for tobacco legislation despite the intransigence of cigarette manufacturers, and he promises residents of tobacco-growing community that their livelihoods will not be threatened by bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As part of a management shake-up at Oxford Health Plans Inc., two senior executives are leaving the company, according to people who have been briefed about their plans. The departures of Robert M. Smoler, who headed the plan for the New York region, where Oxford is one of the largest managed care companies, and David B. Snow Jr., an executive vice president, are expected to be announced next week. A spokeswoman for Oxford, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., declined to comment.
docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc senior executives Robert M Smoler and David B Snow Jr are leaving the company (S)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Four months after multiple-bypass heart surgery, Gordon Kernan, 52, was back at work testing products at the Black & Decker Corporation. But his diabetes grew worse after the operation, so he now monitors his health with the help of a counseling program that his employer helped create. Every few weeks, Amie Layman, a trained diabetes counselor, calls Mr. Kernan and his wife, Mary, with encouragement and advice on exercise and diet. When one medication caused problems, Ms. Layman suggested seeing a specialist, who quickly switched Mr. Kernan to a different medicine. ''If it hadn't been for Amie,'' Mrs. Kernan said, ''I could have lost him.''

headline.main: Taking Care of Workers And Business, Too; When Quality Is Key in Health Benefits

docs.abstract: More and more companies, faced with backlash against penny-pinching managed health care, are taking harder look at that care, often sponsoring programs to help employees and their families cope with chronic maladies; companies, while continuing to insist on keeping costs as low as possible, are now pushing for quality in variety of ways; beyond motivation of keeping employees happy, many companies are also trying to appear responsive to such concerns to help avoid more intrusive Government regulation; some companies are working directly with doctors and hospitals on improving treatments, while others press insurers and health maintenance organizations to offer special programs for certain medical conditions; some specific programs detailed; chart; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In her 10 years as a nurse at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, Jackie Francois has become a big fan of her unusual work schedule: three 12-hour shifts a week. It allows Ms. Francois, a nurse in the surgical intensive care unit, to stay at home two or three weekdays each week, enabling her to call for her 10-year-old daughter at school, help her with her homework and spend time with her. It also gives Ms. Francois the chance to take advanced nursing courses. And it gives her four days a week to decompress from her high-stress job.

headline.main: Hospital and Striking Nurses Face Off Over 12-Hour Shifts

docs.abstract: Strike by nurses at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn enters its tenth day with major issue being hospital's attempt to replace three 12-hour shifts per week with five eight-hour shifts; affect strike has had on residents of Borough Park discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, where disputes about arcane accounting practices can lead to blows and lawsuits, almost no company is argued over more than Conseco Inc. -- except maybe Green Tree Financial. Yesterday, they announced they were merging to become one very controversial company. Conseco is an insurance conglomerate that has grown swiftly by buying 19 smaller businesses since 1982, using accounting methods that some analysts say has made the company's business hard to value. Green Tree, which lends money to people who buy mobile homes, recently had to restate its 1996 earnings, which forced its chairman, Lawrence M. Coss, to return about $23 million of the $102 million bonus he received for the year.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Conseco and Green Tree, an Improbable Merger

docs.abstract: Conseco Inc agrees to acquire Green Tree Financial Corp in stock deal worth $7.6 billion; Green Tree's shares, which had fallen steeply since its accounting problems became known last fall, rise sharply on early-morning news, opening at $44, up from $29; stock closes at $38.875; shares of Conseco, which hit record high on April 6, close at $49.125, a decline of 15 percent; drop shaves about $1 billion off value of deal; Conseco's chairman Stephen C Hilbert says drop is not not reflection of the deal (Market Place column) (L)
docs.snippet: On Wall Street, where disputes about arcane accounting practices can lead to blows and lawsuits, almost no company is argued over more than Conseco Inc. -- except maybe Green Tree Financial. Yesterday, they announced they were merging to become one...

docs.lead_paragraph: With charts at his side and an array of solutions being debated before him, President Clinton began trying to build consensus today on addressing Social Security's looming financial problems, and he said he thought the job could be accomplished without raising the payroll taxes that finance the retirement system. Speaking to the first of four regional conferences on Social Security this year, Mr. Clinton for the most part kept to generalities and left open the possibility of sweeping changes, including the proposal to make individual investment accounts a part of what until now has been solely a guaranteed Government benefit program.

headline.main: PRESIDENT PRESSES DEBATE ON CHANGE IN SOCIAL SECURITY

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton visits Kansas City for first of four regional conferences addressing Social Security's looming financial problems, with goal of building consensus for change; photo; his first discussion leaves open possibility of sweeping changes, although he all but rules out raising 12.4 percent payroll tax rate, and says he would be reluctant to eliminate earnings cap, now $68,400; Clinton points out that current economic health offers rare chance to prepare to insure strong benefits for baby boom generation without placing undue burden on younger people; indicates he would agree to proposed individual retirement accounts only if guaranteed benefit is maintained; such accounts are supported by other lawmakers who also speak (M)
